awd_titl_txt: Testing the mating system model for the evolution of parasite complex life-cycles
awd_abstract_narration:
Parasites can have complex life cycles that involve two or three different host species. Why such complex life cycles persist has long puzzled biologists. This research project will test the theory that the complex life cycles of parasites are maintained or generated by the need to avoid inbreeding, i.e., mating with relatives.  It will specifically test whether inbreeding has negative effects on fitness, such as reduced survival or reproduction. The study will be made a parasitic fluke species that has some populations that require three hosts and other populations that require only two hosts. This variation in number of hosts presents an ideal opportunity to test an important mating system model in evolutionary theory.  The results will also provide key insights into infectious disease transmission relating to the potential for parasites to infect new host species.  The project provides research opportunities and training for graduate and undergraduate students in the fields of parasitology and population genetics. Undergraduates from under-represented groups will be recruited from the Texas A&M Regents Scholars (low income, first generation students) program and Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation. 

This project will test the mating system model, which proposes that parasite mating systems maintain or generate complex life cycles, specifically that the cost of losing a host is to increase inbreeding. The project has two major aims. Aim 1 will test the underlying assumption of the model that a more complex life cycle will have less inbreeding compared to a simpler life cycle. Aim 2 will test the prediction of the model that inbreeding depression is not manifested when evolving a simpler life cycle. To address these questions, population genetic comparisons will be made within and between species in the trematode genus Alloglossidium. This study system provides an opportunity to test the mating system model because of its among-population variation in life cycle complexity. Populations will be compared for the amount of inbreeding and its potential association with fitness reductions.  The results will have an impact on models of evolution concerning host-parasite life cycles and fitness.

por.por_cntn:
Life cycle complexity, which includes both host species and number of hosts in the life cycle, is one of the most fundamental and intriguing components of parasite ecology and evolution. Many parasites require more than one host to complete their development. How such complex life cycles evolved or are maintained has long puzzled biologists. This research project is scientifically important because it will test an existing theory that parasite complex cycles are maintained or generated by the need to avoid inbreeding (i.e., self-mating for a hermaphroditic organism or mating with relatives) and hence, prevent the possible negative effects inbreeding depression (i.e., reduced survival or reproduction) associated with inbreeding. Results from this study will make a significant contribution to the broader theory on the evolution of what is considered one of the major adaptive features of a parasitic lifestyle, i.e., life cycle complexity. Such knowledge is necessary to provide key insights into infectious disease transmission and the potential for parasites to infect new host species. Our goals were to test a key assumption and main prediction of the mating system model of complex life cycle evolution. Specifically, our aims tested 1) the model assumption that when there is a life cycle reduction in host number, there will be a change in the mating system that leads to increased inbreeding, and 2) the prediction that inbreeding depression is not manifested when evolving a life cycle with fewer hosts. Within- and between-species, population genetic comparisons of trematodes in the genus Alloglossidium were used to address these aims. The central hypothesis was that a change in parasite life cycle complexity can alter a parasite’s mating system (i.e., modify hermaphroditic outcrossing opportunities) and thus, have the evolutionary consequence of altering the degree of inbreeding within the parasite population.

We accomplished our goals both in terms of the intellectual merit contributions to the scientific community and of the broader impact contributions to benefit society, i.e., providing trainee support to generate a STEM workforce and conducting public outreach. There were 9 publications, 1 submitted manuscript, 3 manuscripts in preparation, and 11 conference presentations that stemmed from this proposal, thereby demonstrating successful completion of the proposed intellectual merit goals. One key study provided the first empirical tests supporting the assumption and prediction of the above-mentioned mating system model of complex life cycle evolution. That is, in A. renale, which has a truncated life cycle, there were high levels of inbreeding, but no evidence of inbreeding depression. Novel methods, which will benefit the scientific community, were developed to conduct an inbreeding depression analysis from field-collected data. Another key study in A. progeneticum, also found support for the model by comparing mating systems among populations of this species that differ in life cycle complexity: some populations have an obligate 3-host life cycle and some have a facultative 2- or 3-host life cycle. Other key contributions include studies wherein we developed key metrics to understand how trematode clonal transmission dynamics can be quantified and assessed for their impact on mating systems and a means to assess inbreeding depression across flatworm parasite life stages.

We accomplished our broader impact goals by having several societal contributions. The training outcomes of this project were successful in enhancing the STEM workforce, especially considering Covid shutdowns at a key time in the grant. One MS student graduated and went on to be a lab manager in a genetics lab. One PhD student graduated and obtained a competitive postdoctoral fellowship at a biomedical research institute where she will use her evolutionary parasitology skill set to study an important trematode of human health concern. One undergrad went on to dental school and another, who was funded by an REU supplement, went on to a doctoral program in biochemistry. The project generated R applications for analysis of the distribution of parasite infections within hosts as well as randomization methods for testing co-transmission of related parasites. These applications are available to the broader scientific community. Lastly, we conducted public outreach where we co-hosted (with partners in the A&M Veterinary School) a booth annually during the Darwin Day celebration at Texas A&M. Also, in 2022, when the American Society of Parasitologists held its meeting in College Station, TX, the PI organized a successful public family outreach event called “Parasitology on the Green” where parasitologists from across the U.S. provided interactive displays to educate the public on parasitological research.
